elements.content: <ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp015" view="all">Thirteen novel 3d–4f heteronuclear coordination polymers based on the pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pda) and imidazole ligands, HIm[(pda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>MLn(Im)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (Im<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>imidazole; M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Co, Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Pr (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), Gd (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), Dy (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), Er (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>); M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Mn, Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Pr (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>), Sm (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>), Gd (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>), Dy (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>), Er (<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>)), HIm[(pda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CoSm(Im)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>10</ce:bold>), [(Im)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>M(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][(pda)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>La<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Co (<ce:bold>11</ce:bold>), Mn (<ce:bold>12</ce:bold>)), and [(pda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Pr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>13</ce:bold>), have been prepared and structurally characterized. X-ray crystallographic analyses revealed that these complexes display four different types of structures. Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>9</ce:bold> are isostructural, and possess 1-D chain structures constructed by alternately arrayed nine-coordinated Ln(III) (Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Pr, Sm, Gd, Dy, Er) and six-coordinated M(II) (M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Mn, Co) ions. Complex <ce:bold>10</ce:bold> exhibits a unique one-dimensional structure, in which two independent chains are parallel viewed down the <ce:italic>a-</ce:italic>axis and anti-parallel viewed down the <ce:italic>c-</ce:italic>axis. Complexes <ce:bold>11</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>12</ce:bold> are isostructural and display 1-D homometallic chain structures. Complex <ce:bold>13</ce:bold> is a 3D framework fabricated through PrN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> and CoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> polyhedrons as building blocks. The variable-temperature solid-state dc magnetic susceptibilities of complexes <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>9</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>13</ce:bold> have been investigated. elements.clean_text:
Abstract
Thirteen novel 3d–4f heteronuclear coordination polymers based on the pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (H2pda) and imidazole ligands, HIm[(pda)3MLn(Im)2(H2O)2]·3H2O (Im=imidazole; M=Co, Ln=Pr (1), Gd (2), Dy (3), Er (4); M=Mn, Ln=Pr (5), Sm (6), Gd (7), Dy (8), Er (9)), HIm[(pda)3CoSm(Im)2(H2O)2]·2H2O (10), [(Im)4M(H2O)2][(pda)4La2(H2O)2]·2H2O (M=Co (11), Mn (12)), and [(pda)6Co3Pr2(H2O)6]·6H2O (13), have been prepared and structurally characterized. X-ray crystallographic analyses revealed that these complexes display four different types of structures. Complexes 1–9 are isostructural, and possess 1-D chain structures constructed by alternately arrayed nine-coordinated Ln(III) (Ln=Pr, Sm, Gd, Dy, Er) and six-coordinated M(II) (M=Mn, Co) ions. Complex 10 exhibits a unique one-dimensional structure, in which two independent chains are parallel viewed down the a-axis and anti-parallel viewed down the c-axis. Complexes 11 and 12 are isostructural and display 1-D homometallic chain structures. Complex 13 is a 3D framework fabricated through PrN3O6 and CoO6 polyhedrons as building blocks. The variable-temperature solid-state dc magnetic susceptibilities of complexes 2, 3, 4, 9 and 13 have been investigated. Antiferromagnetic exchange interactions were determined for these five complexes.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">The design and synthesis of 3d–4f heterometallic coordination polymers have attracted increasing attention . The interests in these polymers span from pure academic aspects of chemistry and physics to applications as functional materials in magnetism , molecular adsorption , catalysis , and light conversion devices . However, the preparation of 3d–4f coordination polymers has certain difficulties. There are two important factors that cause the synthetic challenge. Firstly, the variable and high coordination numbers of the trivalent lanthanide ions make the coordination geometries of the polymers uncontrollable. Secondly, since rare earth metal ions behave as hard acid and prefer oxygen to nitrogen atoms, while 3d transition metal ions have a strong tendency to coordinate N-donors as well as O-donors, it is quite possible that the competition between 3d and 4f metals in coordinating to the same ligand gives rise to homometallic coordination polymers rather than heterometallic ones. Therefore, one of the synthetic strategies in building such polymers is to employ appropriate bridging ligands, which have bonding site with differential affinities in order to discriminate different metal ions. To date, a few types of multidentate ligands containing N- and O-donors, e.g., pyridine-dicarboxylic acids , amino acid , Schiff-base , etc., have been reported in the literature. Among them, pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pda) is a good ligand for the preparation of high dimensional 3d–4f metal coordination polymers, because H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>dpa displays several coordination modes, such as O-unidentate , O, N-bidentate , O, N, O-tridentate , (O, N) O-bidentate bridging , (O, N, O) O and O, N, <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>-O-tridentate bridging . The diverse coordination modes of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pda largely contributed to the formation of the aesthetically pleasing structures. Moreover, when coordinating to 4f metal ions, pda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> adopts a tridentate mode: the N atom coordinates with two O atoms from two adjacent carboxylic groups (each carboxylic group provides one O atom), while the other O atoms of the carboxylic groups coordinate to 3d metal ions. The use of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>dpa had previously given a number of heteronuclear coordination polymers . Remarkably, it is found that the polymers with designed structural motifs have been resulted by dexterously combining H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pda with another properly selected ancillary ligand .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
The design and synthesis of 3d–4f heterometallic coordination polymers have attracted increasing attention . The interests in these polymers span from pure academic aspects of chemistry and physics to applications as functional materials in magnetism , molecular adsorption , catalysis , and light conversion devices . However, the preparation of 3d–4f coordination polymers has certain difficulties. There are two important factors that cause the synthetic challenge. Firstly, the variable and high coordination numbers of the trivalent lanthanide ions make the coordination geometries of the polymers uncontrollable. Secondly, since rare earth metal ions behave as hard acid and prefer oxygen to nitrogen atoms, while 3d transition metal ions have a strong tendency to coordinate N-donors as well as O-donors, it is quite possible that the competition between 3d and 4f metals in coordinating to the same ligand gives rise to homometallic coordination polymers rather than heterometallic ones. Therefore, one of the synthetic strategies in building such polymers is to employ appropriate bridging ligands, which have bonding site with differential affinities in order to discriminate different metal ions. To date, a few types of multidentate ligands containing N- and O-donors, e.g., pyridine-dicarboxylic acids , amino acid , Schiff-base , etc., have been reported in the literature. Among them, pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid (H2pda) is a good ligand for the preparation of high dimensional 3d–4f metal coordination polymers, because H2dpa displays several coordination modes, such as O-unidentate , O, N-bidentate , O, N, O-tridentate , (O, N) O-bidentate bridging , (O, N, O) O and O, N, μ-O-tridentate bridging . The diverse coordination modes of H2pda largely contributed to the formation of the aesthetically pleasing structures. Moreover, when coordinating to 4f metal ions, pda2− adopts a tridentate mode: the N atom coordinates with two O atoms from two adjacent carboxylic groups (each carboxylic group provides one O atom), while the other O atoms of the carboxylic groups coordinate to 3d metal ions. The use of H2dpa had previously given a number of heteronuclear coordination polymers . Remarkably, it is found that the polymers with designed structural motifs have been resulted by dexterously combining H2pda with another properly selected ancillary ligand .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">We are interested in the combination of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pda with imidazole. H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pda could simultaneous chelate with lanthanide ions and bridge transition metal ions, and imidazole tends to coordinate with transition metal ions, preventing the formation of homometallic coordination polymers. Employment of imidazole as an ancillary ligand could also prevent H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O from coordinating with metal ions and increase the thermal stability of the resulting polymers .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: We are interested in the combination of H2pda with imidazole. H2pda could simultaneous chelate with lanthanide ions and bridge transition metal ions, and imidazole tends to coordinate with transition metal ions, preventing the formation of homometallic coordination polymers. Employment of imidazole as an ancillary ligand could also prevent H2O from coordinating with metal ions and increase the thermal stability of the resulting polymers .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Complexes containing the H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pda and imidazole ligands have not been reported before. Heterometallic 3d–4f complexes containing both lanthanide (4f) and transition (3d) metals are mostly focused on the lanthanide–copper (Ln–Cu) system , while those with lanthanide–cobalt  (or manganese ) metals are scarce. In the present work, we have used H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pda in combination with imidazole for the synthesis of some interesting 1-D and 3-D Co(II)–Ln(III) and Mn(II)–Ln(III) coordination polymers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Complexes containing the H2pda and imidazole ligands have not been reported before. Heterometallic 3d–4f complexes containing both lanthanide (4f) and transition (3d) metals are mostly focused on the lanthanide–copper (Ln–Cu) system , while those with lanthanide–cobalt  (or manganese ) metals are scarce. In the present work, we have used H2pda in combination with imidazole for the synthesis of some interesting 1-D and 3-D Co(II)–Ln(III) and Mn(II)–Ln(III) coordination polymers.

The magnetic properties of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>9</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>13</ce:bold> have been investigated.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The results of present investigation provide 13 interesting 3d–4f coordination polymeric complexes: HIm[(pda)3MLn(Im)2(H2O)2]·3H2O (H2pda=pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid, Im=imidazole, M=Co, Ln=Pr (1), Gd (2), Dy (3), Er (4); M=Mn, Ln=Pr (5), Sm (6), Gd (7), Dy (8), Er (9)), HIm[(pda)3CoSm(Im)2(H2O)2]·2H2O (10), [(Im)4M(H2O)2][(pda)4La2(H2O)2]·2H2O (M=Co (11), Mn (12)), and [(pda)6Co3Pr2(H2O)6]·6H2O (13). The magnetic properties of 2, 3, 4, 9 and 13 have been investigated.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental
General procedure
Ln(NO3)3·6H2O was prepared by dissolving Ln2O3 in dilute nitric acid followed by drying and crystallization. Other chemicals were purchased from commercial suppliers and used without further purification. The C, H and N microanalyses were carried out with a Carlo-Erba EA1110 CHNO-S elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range of 400–4000cm−1 on a Nicolet MagNa-IR500 spectrometer. Crystal determination was performed with a Bruker SMART APEX ΙΙ CCDC diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromatized MoKα radiation (λ
=0.71073Å). Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities were measured with a Quantum Design MPMS-7 SQUID magnetometer. Diamagnetic corrections were made with Pascal’s constants for all constituent atoms. The elemental analysis results are listed in 
.

Crystal structure refinement
Data were collected at room temperature; the ω
−2φ scan technique was applied. The structures were solved by direct methods using shelxs-97  and refined on F
2 using full-matrix least-squares with shelxl-97 . Crystallographic data together with refinement details for the complexes reported in this work were summarized in 
. Selected bond lengths and angles for complexes 1–13 were given in .

elements.clean_text:
Preparations
Synthesis of HIm[(pda)3CoLn(Im)2(H2O)2]·3H2O (Ln=Pr (1), Gd (2), Dy (3), Er (4))
A mixture solution of H2pda (0.0334g, 0.2mmol), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0291g, 0.1mmol), Ln(NO3)3·6H2O (0.0217–0.238g, 0.05mmol), Im (0.0382g, 0.56mmol), H2O/C2H5OH (3mL, v/v=2:1) was sealed in a Pyrex-tube (8mL). The tube was heated at 90°C for 4days under autogenously pressure. The resultant solution was gradually cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5°C/h. Pink crystals were obtained. The crystals were collected by filtration, washed with H2O (3mL) and dried in air. IR (KBr, cm−1): (1): 3454 (br), 1616 (s), 1572 (s), 1433 (s), 1389 (s), 1273 (s), 1186 (s), 1072 (s), 1014 (s), 769 (s), 727 (s), 659 (s); (2): 3417 (br), 1636 (s), 1581 (s), 1431 (s), 1384 (s), 1277 (s), 1069 (s), 1021 (s), 731 (s), 662 (s); (3): 3372 (br), 1636 (s), 1582 (s), 1435 (s), 1389 (s), 1281 (s), 1188 (s), 1072 (s), 1022 (s), 922 (s), 733 (s), 664 (s); (4): 3428 (br), 1656 (s), 1569 (s), 1384 (s), 1269 (s), 1204 (s), 1078 (s), 1020 (s), 935 (s), 770 (s), 734 (s), 661 (s).

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">All complexes were prepared under solvothermal conditions in H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O/C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>OH (v/v<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2:1) in sealed reaction vessels, allowing high-temperature reactions and under favorable conditions for crystallizations of products direct from the reaction solution.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion
Synthesis
All complexes were prepared under solvothermal conditions in H2O/C2H5OH (v/v=2:1) in sealed reaction vessels, allowing high-temperature reactions and under favorable conditions for crystallizations of products direct from the reaction solution.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0070" view="all">The employment of EtOH as co-solvent favors the formation of the crystals. In the absence of EtOH, powder forms of the coordination polymers were obtained. EtOH may hinder the diffusion of crystallization nutrients in the reaction system and make the crystal growth slower and more homogeneous.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The employment of EtOH as co-solvent favors the formation of the crystals. In the absence of EtOH, powder forms of the coordination polymers were obtained. EtOH may hinder the diffusion of crystallization nutrients in the reaction system and make the crystal growth slower and more homogeneous.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0075" view="all">Imidazole plays virtual roles in the crystal growth process. It coordinates with Co (or Mn) atoms and balances the charge as discussed below. On the other hand, the amount of the imidazole influences the crystal structures of the complexes. In the Co–Pr–pda system, two types of crystals were obtained by slightly changing the weight of the imidazole. In the other systems, only one type of 3d–4f complex could be yielded if the amount of imidazole is slightly changed.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Imidazole plays virtual roles in the crystal growth process. It coordinates with Co (or Mn) atoms and balances the charge as discussed below. On the other hand, the amount of the imidazole influences the crystal structures of the complexes. In the Co–Pr–pda system, two types of crystals were obtained by slightly changing the weight of the imidazole. In the other systems, only one type of 3d–4f complex could be yielded if the amount of imidazole is slightly changed.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Description of structures</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Crystal structure of HIm[(pda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CoPr(Im)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">The X-ray crystallography analysis reveals that the crystal of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is made up of an anionic ([(DPA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CoPr(Im)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) zigzag chain, lattice water molecules and protonated imidazole ions. The coordination environments of Pr(III) and Co(II) ions are shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>a and the chain structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is displayed in b. As shown in a, Pr(III) ion shows a coordination number of nine with a nearly tricapped trigonal prism geometry. The Pr1 center is chelated by three tridentate pda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions through three nitrogen atoms (N1, N2, and N1A) and six oxygen atoms (O1, O3, O5, O1A, O3A, and O5A). The bond lengths of Pr1–O and Pr1–N are in the range of 2.474(4)–2.497(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and 2.597(6)–2.598(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively, all of which are within the range of those observed for other related Pr(III) complexes .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Description of structures
Crystal structure of HIm[(pda)3CoPr(Im)2(H2O)2]·3H2O (1)
The X-ray crystallography analysis reveals that the crystal of 1 is made up of an anionic ([(DPA)3CoPr(Im)2(H2O)2]−) zigzag chain, lattice water molecules and protonated imidazole ions. The coordination environments of Pr(III) and Co(II) ions are shown in 
a and the chain structure of 1 is displayed in b. As shown in a, Pr(III) ion shows a coordination number of nine with a nearly tricapped trigonal prism geometry. The Pr1 center is chelated by three tridentate pda2− anions through three nitrogen atoms (N1, N2, and N1A) and six oxygen atoms (O1, O3, O5, O1A, O3A, and O5A). The bond lengths of Pr1–O and Pr1–N are in the range of 2.474(4)–2.497(4)Å and 2.597(6)–2.598(5)Å, respectively, all of which are within the range of those observed for other related Pr(III) complexes .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0085" view="all">The Co(II) ion is coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2 and O2A) from pda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anion, two nitrogen atoms (N3 and N3A) from two imidazole molecules and two oxygen atoms from two water molecules (O7 and O7A). Thus the six atoms around Co2 form a nearly octahedral geometry. The O2, O2A, O7 and O7A atoms constitute the equatorial plane of the octahedron, whereas the N3 and N3A atoms are at the axial position. The bond lengths of Co2–O2, Co2–O7 and Co2–N3 are 2.115(4), 2.109(4) and 2.113(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively, falling into the average Co–O (carboxylic) distance  of 2.120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and Co–N (imidazole) distance of 2.110<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The Co(II) ion is coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2 and O2A) from pda2− anion, two nitrogen atoms (N3 and N3A) from two imidazole molecules and two oxygen atoms from two water molecules (O7 and O7A). Thus the six atoms around Co2 form a nearly octahedral geometry. The O2, O2A, O7 and O7A atoms constitute the equatorial plane of the octahedron, whereas the N3 and N3A atoms are at the axial position. The bond lengths of Co2–O2, Co2–O7 and Co2–N3 are 2.115(4), 2.109(4) and 2.113(5)Å, respectively, falling into the average Co–O (carboxylic) distance  of 2.120Å and Co–N (imidazole) distance of 2.110Å .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0090" view="all">The one-dimensional chain is formed by PrO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> polyhedron and CoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> polyhedron in which the Pr(III) and Co(II) ions are arrayed alternately and connected through O1–C6–O2 bridges (b). The distance between Pr1 atom and Co2 ion is 5.872<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The one-dimensional chain is formed by PrO6N3 polyhedron and CoO4N2 polyhedron in which the Pr(III) and Co(II) ions are arrayed alternately and connected through O1–C6–O2 bridges (b). The distance between Pr1 atom and Co2 ion is 5.872Å.

elements.clean_text:
To the best of our knowledge, this type of 3d–4f heterometallic coordination polymer with 1D alternating zigzag chain structure has never been reported.
Crystal structure of HIm[(pda)3CoSm(Im)2(H2O)2]·2H2O (10)
The structure of 10 is composed of two 1D chains of alternating nine coordinated Sm(III) and six coordinated Co(II). The coordination environments of Sm(III) and Co(II) ions () are similar to those of in 1.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0115" view="all">The two zigzag chains of Sm(III)–pda–Co(II) are parallel and have the shape of a sine wave extending in the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-axis direction (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>a and b). When viewed down <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-axis, the two chains adopt an anti-parallel disposition, as if the two sine wave curves fluctuating up and down with the different phase. This type of structure has never been reported for 3d–4f heterometallic coordination polymers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The two zigzag chains of Sm(III)–pda–Co(II) are parallel and have the shape of a sine wave extending in the a-axis direction (
a and b). When viewed down c-axis, the two chains adopt an anti-parallel disposition, as if the two sine wave curves fluctuating up and down with the different phase. This type of structure has never been reported for 3d–4f heterometallic coordination polymers.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Crystal structure of [(Im)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Co(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][(pda)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>La<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>11</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0125" view="all">The complex <ce:bold>11</ce:bold> consists of 1D linear chain of [(pda)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>La<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>, [Co(Im)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions and solvent water molecules. In the structure of the chain (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>a), all La(III) ions show a coordination number of nine with a slightly distort tricapped trigonal prism geometry. The La(III) center is chelated by two tridentate pda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions through two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N2) and four oxygen atoms (O1, O3, O5, and O7), one bridging carboxylate oxygen atom (O5A) from neighboring pda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anion, one carboxylate oxygen atom (O8A) from neighboring pda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anion and one oxygen atom from water molecule (O9). There are two kinds of bridges in this anion: (1) two metal La(III) ions are doubly bridged by two carboxylate oxygen atoms thus attaining nine-coordination where the La–La distance is found to be 4.45<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; (2) two La(III) ions are connected through O7–C14–O8 bridge of the coordinated pda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anion, where the La–La distance is found to be 6.343<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. These two bridges propagate the polymeric chain approximately along the crystallographic <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis. The distances of Ln–O bond range from 2.5232(14) to 2.5931(13)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, all of which are within the range of these observed for other related La(III) complexes . The O–La–O bond angles fall in the range of 64.80(5)–160.93(4)°.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of [(Im)4Co(H2O)2][(pda)4La2(H2O)2]·2H2O (11)
The complex 11 consists of 1D linear chain of [(pda)4La2(H2O)2]2−, [Co(Im)4(H2O)2]2+ ions and solvent water molecules. In the structure of the chain (
a), all La(III) ions show a coordination number of nine with a slightly distort tricapped trigonal prism geometry. The La(III) center is chelated by two tridentate pda2− anions through two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N2) and four oxygen atoms (O1, O3, O5, and O7), one bridging carboxylate oxygen atom (O5A) from neighboring pda2− anion, one carboxylate oxygen atom (O8A) from neighboring pda2− anion and one oxygen atom from water molecule (O9). There are two kinds of bridges in this anion: (1) two metal La(III) ions are doubly bridged by two carboxylate oxygen atoms thus attaining nine-coordination where the La–La distance is found to be 4.45Å; (2) two La(III) ions are connected through O7–C14–O8 bridge of the coordinated pda2− anion, where the La–La distance is found to be 6.343Å. These two bridges propagate the polymeric chain approximately along the crystallographic c axis. The distances of Ln–O bond range from 2.5232(14) to 2.5931(13)Å, all of which are within the range of these observed for other related La(III) complexes . The O–La–O bond angles fall in the range of 64.80(5)–160.93(4)°.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0130" view="all">The Co(II) ion is six coordinated by four nitrogen atoms (N3, N5, N3A, and N5A) from four imidazole molecules and two oxygen atoms from two water molecules (O10 and O10A), forming slightly distorted octahedral geometry. The bond lengths of Co3–O10, Co3–N3 and Co3–N5 are 2.1680(15), 2.1211(17) and 2.1472(16)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively.</ce:para>

The bond lengths of Co3–O10, Co3–N3 and Co3–N5 are 2.1680(15), 2.1211(17) and 2.1472(16)Å, respectively.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0135" view="all">Uncoordinated water molecules link the anionic chains and cationic [Co(Im)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> units through hydrogen bonding to form a 3D supramolecular structure (b).</ce:para><ce:para id="p0140" view="all">Complexes <ce:bold>12</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>11</ce:bold> are isostructural, and thus the structure of <ce:bold>12</ce:bold> will not be discussed in detail.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Crystal structure of [(pda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Pr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>13</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0145" view="all">The crystal structure of <ce:bold>13</ce:bold> is constructed by two building blocks, PrN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> and CoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>a). The Pr(III) center is chelated by three tridentate pda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions through three nitrogen atoms and six oxygen atoms. The coordination geometry of Pr(III) ion conforms closely to a tricapped trigonal prism. The Co(II) ion is coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from pda<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions and two oxygen atoms from two water molecules. Thus the six atoms around Co(II) ion form an enlongate octahedral geometry. Each carboxylate group has one oxygen atom coordinated to Co(II) ions, which indicates that each Pr(III) ion is encircled by six Co(II) ions and each Co(II) ion is surrounded by four Pr(III) ions. As a result of this connectivity pattern, a 2D planar structure is formed with Ln polyhedron. The layers are further connected via Co(II) ions, and then a 3D framework is developed (b).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Uncoordinated water molecules link the anionic chains and cationic [Co(Im)4(H2O)2]2+ units through hydrogen bonding to form a 3D supramolecular structure (b).
Complexes 12 and 11 are isostructural, and thus the structure of 12 will not be discussed in detail.
Crystal structure of [(pda)6Co3Pr2(H2O)6]·6H2O (13)
The crystal structure of 13 is constructed by two building blocks, PrN3O6 and CoO6 (
a). The Pr(III) center is chelated by three tridentate pda2− anions through three nitrogen atoms and six oxygen atoms. The coordination geometry of Pr(III) ion conforms closely to a tricapped trigonal prism. The Co(II) ion is coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from pda2− anions and two oxygen atoms from two water molecules. Thus the six atoms around Co(II) ion form an enlongate octahedral geometry. Each carboxylate group has one oxygen atom coordinated to Co(II) ions, which indicates that each Pr(III) ion is encircled by six Co(II) ions and each Co(II) ion is surrounded by four Pr(III) ions. As a result of this connectivity pattern, a 2D planar structure is formed with Ln polyhedron. The layers are further connected via Co(II) ions, and then a 3D framework is developed (b).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0150" view="all">Viewed down <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-axis, the PrN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> polyhedron and CoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> polyhedron are alternating arrayed to generate a dodecanuclear heterometallic Pr<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>Co<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> circular unit. Interestingly, when viewed down the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-axis, the solvent water molecules of the complex are arrayed as a circle too, which is located inside the heterometallic Pr<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>Co<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> circular unit. By calculation using the Platon, the rate of the Pr<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>Co<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> circular unit is 21.9%, and the total potential volume of the solvent area is 695.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Viewed down c-axis, the PrN3O6 polyhedron and CoO6 polyhedron are alternating arrayed to generate a dodecanuclear heterometallic Pr6Co6 circular unit. Interestingly, when viewed down the c-axis, the solvent water molecules of the complex are arrayed as a circle too, which is located inside the heterometallic Pr6Co6 circular unit. By calculation using the Platon, the rate of the Pr6Co6 circular unit is 21.9%, and the total potential volume of the solvent area is 695.8Å3.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0185" view="all">This work focused on the systematic investigation on the overall molecular architectures constructed from combination of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>pda ligand with imidazole. Thirteen different attractive types of 3d–4f heteronuclear coordination polymers have been prepared by solvothermal synthetic method and characterized by IR, elemental analysis and X-ray single crystal diffraction. The complexes display four different types of structures, namely novel 1D heterometallic chain motif (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>), 1D heterometallic double chain structure (<ce:bold>10</ce:bold>), 1D homometallic chain (<ce:bold>11</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>12</ce:bold>) and 3D framework (<ce:bold>13</ce:bold>). The magnetic properties of complexes <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>9</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>13</ce:bold> have been investigated. Antiferromagnetic exchange interactions were determined for all these five complexes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions
This work focused on the systematic investigation on the overall molecular architectures constructed from combination of H2pda ligand with imidazole. Thirteen different attractive types of 3d–4f heteronuclear coordination polymers have been prepared by solvothermal synthetic method and characterized by IR, elemental analysis and X-ray single crystal diffraction. The complexes display four different types of structures, namely novel 1D heterometallic chain motif (1–9), 1D heterometallic double chain structure (10), 1D homometallic chain (11–12) and 3D framework (13). The magnetic properties of complexes 2, 3, 4, 9 and 13 have been investigated. Antiferromagnetic exchange interactions were determined for all these five complexes.
